p: Although these three technologies can be broadly categorized by which is optimal at different carbon prices, variability (and, to a lesser extent, uncertainty) in their RPVs contributes to considerable overlap in the ranges of suitability of the three technologies (see overlapping uncertainty ranges shown by the shaded areas at +/− 1 s.d. ( σ) in Fig. 1a). In the lower carbon-price range below $400 Mg −1 C, BES is most likely ( P=0.44–0.64) to have the highest NPV, while BEBCS has the highest NPV for most other situations ( P=0.37–0.44), BECCS being infrequently ( P<0.1) the most economic biomass power generation technology in this carbon-price range ( Fig. 1b). Although BECCS is typically the technology with highest NPV in the higher carbon-price range (>$1,000 Mg −1 C), even with carbon prices as high as $3,000 Mg −1 C BEBCs remains the most economic technology in 20% of the parameter space ( Fig. 1b).
